content: sloth finished sizeapprox 15cm/ 6in tall long from tip of nose to tip of tail yarn a small amount 4-ply/ fingering weight yarn in beige yarn b small amount 4-ply/ fingering weight yarn in off-white yarn c small amount 4-ply/ fingering weight yarn in dark-grey i used a - drops alpaca 0618 nougat-mix b - drops alpaca 0100 off white c - drops alpaca 0506 dark-grey mix knitting needles pair size 2mm/ us 0 straight knitting needles gauge 12 5 row and 11 stitches over 2 5cm with 2mm needles and 4-ply yarn extras pair 8mm brown toy safety eyes with washers toy filling 16 x locking type stitch markers see colour guide on page 2 scissors and yarn-sewing needle plus if you want to add wire into the limbs and body you ll need two 30cm/ 12in long x 22 or 20 gauge armature wires see note on page 2 this is the website for the wiresheidifeathersonetsy © claire garland © dot pebbles knits sloth page 2 sloth page 3 coloured marker guide special instructions this guide is here to pull out and use together with the pattern w+tk bring working yarn to the front of the work slip next stitch purl-wise should to wish to use similar coloured guides to mine for ease of onto the rh needle take working yarn to the back slip the slipped stitch back following especially at the making-up stage onto the lh needle turn the knitting = w+tk wrap and turn knit head & body w+tp take working yarn to the back of the work slip next stitch knit-wise orangehind leg back onto the rh needle bring working yarn to the front slip the slipped stitch turquoisehind leg front back onto the lh needle turn the knitting = w+tp wrap and turn purl pinkforeleg general abbreviations pale pinkneck k = knit pale turquoiserear end p = purl lime greenneck to inner foreleg increase = increase greenbelly to inner foreleg decrease = decrease bluebelly to hind leg front k2tog/ k3tog = knit two together/ knit three together p2tog/ p3tog = purl two together/ purl three together pattern notes & tips rh/lh = right hand/ left hand rs/ws = right side/ wrong side i cast on with cable cast on method but you can use your regular st/ sts =stitch/ stitches cast-on method if desired skpo = slip one stitch knit next stitch pass slipped stitch over knit stitch to wire i found the best wires to create an armature with are decrease by one stitch paper-wrapped easier to handle ones - the best gauge for this kfb = knit into front then into back of stitch to increase by one stitch project being 20 0 8mm which i used for the legs and body or pfb = purl into front then knit into back of stitch to increase by one stitch slightly finer 22 0 6mm both of which are really malleable and p-wise = purl-wise easy to bend by hand ws =
